abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Special Repurchase
            Facility Support Loan Project for Argentina was
            unsatisfactory, the sustainability was highly unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that the
            standby lending operations can be better suited than
            crisis-reactive loans under some circumstances, particularly
            when the purpose of the former is to prevent crises from
            developing in the first place. While emergency lending, such
            as that provided by the Repurchase Facility Support Loan
            (RFSL), should include terms and conditions that do reflect
            the riskier credit conditions under which is made, it should
            be also taken into account the future ability of the
            receiving country to service such debt. Alternative
            disbursement scenarios of transaction-based
            standby/contingent loans require to be carefully analyzed,
            including an assessment of the Bank's marginal
            contribution. Financial enhancements provided by the Bank
            need to be commensurate with the financial leverage. In the
            case of the RFSL, the lesson is that the amount disbursed by
            the Bank should have been probably tied to the size of the
            repo facility and/or the amounts effectively disbursed by
            participating international banks.
